[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is already in her room.
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
Isobel: You're here for the protection spell, right? Come on - let's get you fit for purpose.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: Curious. Surely the Nightsinger could have shielded all her followers, and made this place her domain long ago... yet she only acts now, and aids you alone. I wonder why.
Player: That's none of your concern.
Isobel: I suppose you're right.
Isobel: I'll stop needling you, though. You have more important things to do, after all.
Player: I do, though I already have a Moonlantern.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! If I'd have realised, I'd have spared the theatrics. In that case, you should be able to navigate a path straight to your target. That's good - very good.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Isobel: You're here for the protection spell, right? Come on - let's get you fit for purpose.
Player: Try to understand what's happening.
Narrator: *Is Lady Shar punishing you? Or perhaps testing you? Is it the tadpole, or a curse? You cannot say.*

Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.

InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
Isobel: You may be a Sharran, but you'll still be better off in those shadows with my Lady's blessing. Just sit still for a moment, please.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: |Casts 'Protection from Good and Evil', but modified with Selunite (moon) magic to protect against the Shadowcurse specifically. Isobel can use the planned animations for this spell cinematically, or something bespoke as best fits the scene. (lighting tests in progree for clouds revealing the moon)

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|

We see every present party member  take on a moon-like effect as a result of being targeted with the spell, which then fades as though absorbed by each of them. This gives them a special in-game status to protect them from the curse|
Narrator: *The blessing falls uneasily over your tainted body. You can't help but dream: to kill her would destroy all of Last Light. You yearn for it so deeply...*
Shadowheart: Ngh... it hurts...
Isobel: Perfect.
Isobel: It'll make you immune to the lesser effects of the shadow curse, which will get you closer to the Towers.
Isobel: But there are places it won't help - places where the curse is darker. Stronger.
Isobel: The cultists are able to traverse even the deepest shadows, though. I don't know how - the Harpers are trying to figure it out.
Shadowheart: Selûnite magic. Dark Lady forgive me.
NodeContext: Low-key revulsion
Isobel: Good nose. Like a nasty little terrier.
Player: Very nice of you, but I've been to Moonrise Towers already.
Isobel: You... have. Forgive me for gilding the lily. I suppose if Jaheira hasn't gone tearing into the night, there's work to be done there yet.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

Isobel: CinematicNodeContext: Isobel not yet kneeling at corpse.
Isobel: What the hells is this?
Narrator: *Your tingling Urge knows her face - this is the cleric Sceleritas sent you to kill.*
Player: He was trying to kidnap you. When he died, a tadpole came out of his head.
Isobel: A tadpole? Maiden's milk - how could that be?
Player: Believe it. He slipped through your fingers, but not mine.
: True
Isobel: In that case, I owe you a debt of gratitude.
Isobel: You're the True Soul from the gate, right? It's a good thing you were here. I'm Isobel. And we have much to discuss.
Player: I may be a True Soul, but I'm not like Marcus. The parasite doesn't control me.
Isobel: If I didn't believe it before, I certainly do now.
Isobel: Speaking of blessings... you'll be needing my protection spell.
Isobel: Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: The True Soul who's going to save us all. Pleased to meet you.
Narrator: *The Urge deep within tingles. This is the one the Butler commanded you to kill.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Narrator: *You choke down the obscene thoughts racking your body with a shiver.*

Isobel: We've been waiting - hoping against hope - for someone like you.
Isobel: Free from the Absolute's influence, yet able to walk among cultists.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. : True

He Who Was: Madeline's spirit is within reach. It is time to make her face trial, to make her suffer.
He Who Was: And you will be the judge. Make her beg, make her suffer.
Player: I'd like to hear her story first - I imagine it's quite the tale.
He Who Was: Careful - for a serpent in life is a serpent in death.
He Who Was: Witness her.
NodeContext: low, excited voice. Eyes roll back in his head as he looks up - body jerking. Falls to his knees.
Madeline: You! He said I was gonna be punished, that you'd be the judge. But I didn't mean to hurt anyone!
Player: You 'didn't mean' to kill your friends? How laughable.
Shadowheart: Oh, come on now - it happens to the best of us, from time to time.
Madeline: I said it didn't mean nothin', that Ben n' Marc were just drunk n' whining.
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar promised she was gonna chat with 'em. She promised.
Player: If it was drunk complaining, why did you report them?
Madeline: The Dark Justiciar said to report everythin', big or small. She ain't the type you say no to.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.
Player: You had the means to stop it - you chose not to. You let fear and cowardice rule you.

Jaheira: Please, be welcome. Have a drink.
Karlach: Oh my gods!
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.
Jaheira: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.
Jaheira: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?
Player: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.
: False
Jaheira: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.
Jaheira: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
Jaheira: To your very good health.
Player: Smell the wine first.
: True
Narrator: *You perceive a faint hint of Klauthgrass, a herb that is said to elicit the truth. Jaheira smiles at you knowingly.*
Jaheira: It doesn't spoil the taste, if that's what you're wondering.
Player: I'm not always in control of my magic - who knows what will happen if I drink this?
Jaheira: You will be refreshed, and I will be reassured.
Player: Drink the wine.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I thought I made myself very clear, civilian. Move along.
Player: You're going to want to see this. Show her the murder target list.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: What makes you think it's not Sarevok himself?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've not ruled out the possibility that it is Sarevok himself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is certainly reminiscent of his work. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You really are a godsend. But - one more thing...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

Narrator: *The lantern gives off a chilly glow, protecting all in its vicinity from the surrounding shadows.*
Harper Manus: I'll be damned - I can feel the light clear down to my bones.
Harper Manus: Farewell, then. And may the path to the Towers rise to meet you.

: False

Player: I know you Fey deal in favours. What do I get for freeing you?
Dolly Dolly Dolly: If you release me from this cell I'll bless you with a faerie spell!
Player: Ignore the pixie. You'll be needing this lamp.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: I'LL GUT YOU LIKE A TEN-DAY-OLD IF YOU DON'T RELEASE ME RIGHT! THIS! MOMENT!
Player: Gutted many ten-day-olds in your day?
Dolly Dolly Dolly: Never give 'em enough rope to hang you.
Dolly Dolly Dolly: If you prefer the kinder type, I'll sweetly slurp your guts like tripe!
Player: Release the pixie.

Rolan: If you're here to save the day again, you're a little late this time.

Rolan: Is that a joke? I wouldn't be here if it wasn't for you.
Rolan: I was ready to cut and run back at the grove, but you had other ideas.
Rolan: Cal and Lia were taken in by your crap. You convinced them to play hero, and now they're gone.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right.

Mayrina: That lying, thieving, scaly little shit. I can't believe I let a hag hurt my own people. Again.
Mayrina: All this blood - and for what? It's just fun and games to her. Damn it all.

Mayrina: Sorry, I'll start at the beginning.
Mayrina: After you saved me from Ethel, I was ashamed - of how stupid I was. How helpless.
Mayrina: So I decided I wasn't going to be a victim anymore.
Mayrina: This group is made of survivors - people like me who've been hurt by hags. I brought them together to fight back.
Mayrina: We tracked a hag to the city, but lost her trail - right after she snatched a little girl.
Player: Any leads on the missing girl?
Mayrina: None. Her mother has no idea of what she's up against. Poor woman thinks the Fist will be able to help her.
Mayrina: The moment I started investigating the missing girl, I felt the hag's eye on me. Next thing, I was sprouting wool and bleating up a storm.
Player: Let me guess - you want me to help.
Mayrina: You've seen what Ethel did - imagine the destruction a hag could cause in a city this size? With people this desperate?
Mayrina: Look, I know you're busy with big-time heroics, but we need your help. A child's life is on the line - and her mother is the best lead we've got.
Player: Of course - a child is in danger. I will do what I can.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: One of us may be able to save themselves, but it would be at the expense of everyone else. We can't risk it.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: We cannot win. We must aid in building these vargh'kron.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?
Player: Recount your investigation into Father Lorgan's murder, and show her the list you found.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: I think it may be another Bhaalspawn...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods save us all if you're right, but I'd believe it. Whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm going to stop my Father, whatever it takes.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?
Player: Show her the list of murder targets.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: I think it may be a Bhaalspawn...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods save us all if you're right, but I'd believe it. Whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm going to stop my Father, whatever it takes.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: Ketheric was a dead man long before we arrived - a servant of Myrkul, Lord of Bones.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed. And now we know that he was not acting alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Is vengeance the limit of your ambitions?
Nightwarden Minthara: There is no limit to my ambitions. I will enjoy killing Orin, but unlike her, I do not kill for pleasure alone. I kill to gain advantage.
Nightwarden Minthara: And we have the chance to seize the greatest advantage of all. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Madness. We need to eradicate the cult and the elder brain.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I thought I made myself very clear, civilian. Move along.
Player: Recount your investigation into Father Lorgan's murder, and show her the list you found.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: I think it may be a Bhaalspawn...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods save us all if you're right, but I'd believe it. Whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'm going to stop my Father, whatever it takes.

Yurgir: You - tiefling. You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.
Karlach: What do you know of infernal machinery?
Yurgir: ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.
Yurgir: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
NodeContext: Furious
Player: I don't know what you mean.
Yurgir: Lies! My nose would recognise him anywhere.
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: I've had dealings with that devil. Maybe we can help each other.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Astarion: What are you doing? The devil told us to kill this thing, so let's stop chatting and kill it.
Player: Attack.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters a gore-soaked alcove and approaches the displacer.There's various severed heads on display - people and monsters. A pile of eviscerated corpses forms a throne-chaise.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment.
Yurgir: But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.
Yurgir: A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere.
Yurgir: You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?
Player: I'm never going back to Avernus. But I'd be happy to send you there.
Yurgir: Such high confidence for someone who reeks so distinctively of fear.
Yurgir: ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.
Yurgir: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
NodeContext: Furious
Player: I'd never ally myself with such a fiend.
Yurgir: Lies! My nose would recognise him anywhere.
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: I've had dealings with that devil. Maybe we can help each other.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Karlach: I'm not one to placate a devil, but the last thing we need is an orthon for an enemy. Fought one once, and my back has never been the same.
Player: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull.
Yurgir: You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract.
Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
Player: Attack.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: I'm with you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I expected you would be, but know this...

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: It suits you.
Nightwarden Minthara: Power always has. But I shall not get too comfortable here.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: When I murder her, Bhaal will choose me in her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you.
Nightwarden Minthara: He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: I'm with you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I expected you would be, but know this...

[description] CinematicNodeContext: The player enters a gore-soaked alcove and approaches the displacer.There's various severed heads on display - people and monsters. A pile of eviscerated corpses forms a throne-chaise.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
There's suddenly a loud click from above (implied to be the orthon racking/loading its crossbow). The player looks up.
The orthon looms on a gallery/crumpling floor overlooking the alcove. It aims a crossbow at the player. Flanking it are several merregons.
Yurgir: What's this? Fresh entertainment.
Yurgir: But you're too fresh for this place, aren't you? You've got the stench of the Hells about you - the stench of home. And a whiff of the surface besides.
Yurgir: A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere.
Yurgir: You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?
Player: What do you know about infernal machinery?
Yurgir: Only what I can smell. And whatever engine burns within you is grinding to an inevitable explosion. Burning and fear - you reek with it.
Yurgir: ...There's something else, almost hidden by your fear-stink... cherries, musk... and sulphur.
NodeContext: Sniffing the air at the start, detecting something - then erupting with fury at the end on 'sulphur'.
Yurgir: Raphael! I can smell him all over you. Where is he?!
NodeContext: Furious
Player: I'd never ally myself with such a fiend.
Yurgir: Lies! My nose would recognise him anywhere.
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: There's nothing stopping you from leaving. I know a way out.
Yurgir: Hah! There's my word. I agreed to a contract - one that hasn't yet been fulfilled.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Wyll: Go on, tell the bastard. All the better for us if he keeps Raphael - busy.
Player: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull.
Yurgir: You can't help. It's not just walls that keep me here. Not the traps, the dark or the creatures it hides. Something stronger holds me - a contract.
Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
Player: Attack.

Yurgir: A servant of Zariel, if I'm not mistaken. I'd know the stench of her infernal machinery anywhere.
Yurgir: You trying to burrow back home, little rabbit?

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: My blood ran hot when we broke Ketheric's bones together. But we have greater challenges ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: An old flame?
Nightwarden Minthara: Jealous? You needn't be -  when Orin is in my hands, her agony will nourish me.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the iblith who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.

NodeContext: Furious
Player: Wait - you know Raphael?
Yurgir: That perfumed trickster swindled me - trapped me.
Player: Perhaps I can help you escape his trap.
Yurgir: Where is he? Spit it out - Now.
Shadowheart: Careful -  I'm not sure we want Raphael as an enemy.
Player: Raphael could be anywhere. But let me go, and I'll free you from his grasp.
Yurgir: Bargaining, are you? A Kara-Tur warlord once tried the same - I made him watch as I ate his concubines and young, then fashioned a codpiece from his skull.

Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
Player: Attack.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: Ketheric was a dead man long before we arrived - a servant of Myrkul, Lord of Bones.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed. And now we know that he was not acting alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: During my time in the cult, I came to know one of his co-conspirators all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: When I murder her, Bhaal will choose me in her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you.
Nightwarden Minthara: He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What do you remember of your indoctrination?
Nightwarden Minthara: When I first visited Moonrise, I stood before the Absolute in awe.
Nightwarden Minthara: It was more of an idea than an entity. Pure love. Total power.
Nightwarden Minthara: Orin was by my side. She told me that god had chosen me to be a True Soul. Blessed and adored.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is as if you read my mind. Perhaps you did.
Player: I'm with you.
Nightwarden Minthara: I expected you would be, but know this...

Yurgir: Either I fulfil the contract, die trying... or forfeit my freedom. If I leave this place now, I'll become Raphael's slave.
